stance_1: I am flexible and intentional about eating meat
stance_2: I listen to my body before eating meat
justification: The interviewee explicitly states that their flexibility and intentionality around eating meat is based on checking in with themselves and listening to their body.

stance_1: I am flexible and intentional about eating meat
stance_2: I skip meat to feel lighter or more energized
justification: The interviewee's flexibility enables them to skip meat when they want to feel lighter or more energized, showing a supportive relationship.

stance_1: I am flexible and intentional about eating meat
stance_2: Social contacts see meat as a habit
justification: The interviewee contrasts their flexible and intentional approach with social contacts who eat meat out of habit, suggesting a conflicting relationship.

stance_1: I am flexible and intentional about eating meat
stance_2: Social contacts often see meat as convenient
justification: The interviewee’s intentional choices are contrasted with the convenience-driven routine of their social contacts, implying a conflict.

stance_1: I crave the taste and texture of meat
stance_2: I eat meat when I crave comfort and fullness
justification: The interviewee explicitly links eating meat to cravings for comfort, fullness, taste, and texture.

stance_1: I eat meat when I crave comfort and fullness
stance_2: I skip meat to feel lighter or more energized
justification: The interviewee directly contrasts eating meat for comfort/fullness with skipping it for lightness/energy.

stance_1: I listen to my body before eating meat
stance_2: I skip meat to feel lighter or more energized
justification: The interviewee explicitly connects listening to their body with the decision to skip meat for energy or lightness.

stance_1: I listen to my body before eating meat
stance_2: I eat meat when I crave comfort and fullness
justification: Listening to one’s body supports eating meat when craving comfort and fullness, as described by the interviewee.

stance_1: I listen to my body before eating meat
stance_2: I crave the taste and texture of meat
justification: Listening to bodily cues can result in craving the taste/texture of meat, showing a supportive relationship.

stance_1: Social contacts often see meat as convenient
stance_2: Social contacts see meat as a habit
